comments.commentBody: There is an amazing material that has been used for many years for flatware. It is called stainless steel. There is also a product that has been successfully used for dishware: washable plastics like melamine resin. China works too. And cups and glasses come in china and glass and washable plastic too. Who knew? Not Congress.

I've been a loyal NYTimes reader since reading it regularly was assigned in my first college political science course in the fall of 1967!  In all these years I haven't missed more than a grand total of perhaps two or three months of individual issues at the newsstand.  I'm retired now, living out in the country where timely NYTimes subscription delivery is impossible.  I've been driving about eight miles round trip each day Monday through Friday for those issues and then again on Sunday for the Saturday and Sunday issues held for me by the nearest newsstand to my home.  I've seen nothing mentioned in your articles about free internet access for those readers who regularly purchase the NYTimes at newsstands.  We're spending as much as, or more than, your home and mail delivery subscribers.  Admittedly it may be awkward for us to prove our regular purchases (proof of purchase bar codes, or perhaps certified letter from the newsvendor).  But there should be some way designed to reward all of us who regularly purchase the NYTimes, yes even those of us antiquated enough to still be purchasing from newsstands.  If daily home delivery subscribers have access, what about those of us who purchase 365 daily issues from newsstands?

I don't have cable, so can not comment on CNN coverage, but the sight of ABC's Diane Sawyer jauntily trotting around devastated neighborhoods, peeking into private homes and making condescending comments about the contents like some sort of perky ghoul was sickening.

Excellent Grant Hill! Now I understand why I loved your father when I was a child [and a HUGE Cowboys fan]. And, now, I'm thankful my son forwarded me your response. He looks up to you like I did your dad.

Keep up the good work! I wish we had more Grant Hill's in this world.

There will be more money won in the office pools trying to guess the day the NYT will pull the plug on this flawed business model than the NYT actually collects from online subscription sales. My money is on April 28th, 2011.
Go Blue

This comment is for readers and the publisher:

You know how when you go to The New York Times website and you click Today's Paper you get The Times in Print. If you then click on Today's Front Pages you get a digital copy of the front page of The New York Times.

Why can't we have digital pages of The New York Times? You know, page A5... page A20... page A28... page B5. Business Day section? You get the idea.

I get The New York Times. Every day. And that's great. I've got a paper copy of Thursday, March 17, 2011. But why can't I read each page of The New York Times on the computer, a laptop, a tablet, ect.?

Why can't there be a digital version of The New York Times with digital pages?

It's interesting how the Fab Five trash talked Duke yet everyone remembers the names of the great Duke team that was Grant's. Thank you for responding in such a positive, intelligent way.  You have always been my favorite athlete and I am proud of how much you continue to give back to Duke. You are an inspiration!
Your thoughtful words are duly noted, Grant. I appreciate your candor, pride, and intelligence.

Jalen Rose has been...Granted an example of the benefits of having two parents with education and common sense. And no matter your race, two parents who respect and love education make a difference in a child's life and their future! What a dignified and gracious response to such utter foolishness and ignorance!

Is the Times worth the amount asked?

Yes.

Will people pay it?

Many will but will they amount to enough to justify the major drop in page hits which may deter advertisers or the ill will generated with those who, like myself, a reader since the early 1950's, no longer can count on unhindered access to our home paper?

I really hope that the paper prospers and that all goes well. You are the best newspaper I have ever read.

Unfortunately, I simply cannot afford $180 a year.

Senior citizens, in many cases, are on fixed incomes and every little bit counts.

I will now read the Times at my local public library.

God bless all of you.
Hold on Jalen. I remember Duke recruiting Chris Webber pretty hard, but he chose Michigan instead.

I am forwarding this to all the haters of Duke fans! When I am asked why I like Duke I never understand why they don't get it. Who wouldn't want a degree from Duke? I love what they offer and instill in their students. This post from a Duke grad put a huge smile on my face and made me feel proud to be a Blue Devil for life!

http://sports.espn.go.com...

People, Jalen Rose's view has NOT really changed. Please watch this newest video (link) before thinking about defending him. It's the second clip on the video list titled 'Standing By Comments About Duke?'

I have to say, I am extremely impressed with the quality of comments on the articles in the past few days covering the nuclear disaster. I have "liked" nearly every one of the responses, particularly those from people in the nuclear industry. It has helped my understanding enormously, and is often times more informative than the article itself.

The inaction of any nation or coalition is striking, almost as if Qaddafi has records of any dignitary who has visited a Libyian cat house or been to a party hosted by his hedonous sons (hello Berlisconi?)
Regardless, any nation worth its salt understands the avionics of any plane on the planet. It is not difficult to jam the signals of fighter planes. What Qaddafi has are not the latest, they are vulnerable.
So...what's the problem?????
A little late guys.

Whew!
At least we're not storing our spent fuel rods right beside our reactors.
Thanks to Harry Reid we're able to store them in the wasteland of Nevada.
And so, because of Harry Reid, NOTHING like this can happen in the USA.
Can it?

I guess so.

A no-fly zone is a much more effective response than economic sanctions. Sanctions merely reinforce the power of the dictator relative to his opposition, and so sanctions confirm the dictator in power. Examples: Cuba, N. Korea, Libya, China, USSR, Iraq, etc. On the other hand, a no-fly zone constrains the military power, and hence the government, of the dictator. Events in Iraq and Serbia enabled refinement of military doctrines for no-fly zones. A no-fly zone is a refined act of war, and acts of war can have unintended consequences. If effected with care to protect civilians from danger, a no-fly zone acts directly on the government of the dictator and diminishes his power relative to his opposition.

comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, New York
comments.commentBody:
To #9

You may be correct - but the underlying assumption you must state is this: the sacrifice may help.

As I believe nothing will help, we disagree.

They are grandstanding. This area is a write off.

They must vacate - in a radius that leaves no doubt.

And that radius will grow.

I do not understand why a large portable generator and pumps can not be brought to the site. Take a hose from the sea, up to the building, and pump it in, The air drops look stupid, like 1/10 maybe getting where it should. How about lead sheilds? Huh, like at the hospital, lead lined drywall placed around to shelter workers. How about the navy and air force doing something. Its like 90 miles to Korea, they have lots of supplies, make great industrial products, can get tents and heaters to the country by air drop in hours. How come the reporters there can not ask simple questions. Like how much power is needed for the pumps. Or at least tell us if stuff has been tried.

Big blunder for the US to get involved in this mess. The colonials, France and Britain should take care off it since they were so eager to silence Al Qaddafi. The vertically challenged French President seems to have particular grudges against the Qaddafi regime.

Maybe the suitcases of banknotes the Brother Colonel gave him to finance his presidential campaign were not enough to buy the loyalty of the modern Napoleon of the Elysées Palace. The whole thing stinks of international corruption and nepotism. Angela Merkel of Germany seems to be the only grown up leader in this mess. A Security Council resolution adopted with 10 votes and 5 abstentions is a sign of very weak international support. I think Mr Obama should have been more cautious. It would be better for the US to stay from the actual military action. For once the French have to show us what fire they have in their small bellies! And by the way who are the rebels in Benghazi? How will they turn if the come to power? And if Egypt take part in military actions will Libya stay quiet? Isn`this an open Pandora`s box? And what about Bahrain? And our
"friends the Saudi"? Lebanon, whose government is under Hezbollah`s rule cosponsored this UN resolution. Are we sleeping with all enemies just to get Qaddafi?
It's to late to help the rebels.  A week ago with all security council  members voting yes, might of had possibilies.   How can we consider getting involved in another war.

And I predict that the UN backed force will be humailated and the Libya will end up becoming second Somalia. Believe it or not it is another failture or mistake the West has already made. They should have rather asked oppositions or militia to stop and demand cease fire but siding with them has ignited one of the most devastating civil war, attrocities, and instability in North Africa. IS that what US wants? If not, then how many times does the US make stupid political miscalculations? This is destasterous political move!

From Australia, as I read the time, it is almost 5 am in the morning, Friday. Egypt may move to the border. Let's hope. In the meantime, the marines, in two assult ships, 4000 strong, should be checking their arms to protect civilains who that despot will look for -- as he says -- "closet by closet" sending a chill down every spine.
